description.narrative: For GA and WOUOL successfully export dried mango and cashew nut products from marginalized small farmers. However, the processing systems of factories are under developed and use unsustainable firewood and butane gas in processing, of which involve high costs and cause environmental damage. Thousands of tonnes of fresh fruit wastes (peels, seeds etc.) require disposal at additional cost. These wastes form environmental hazard as they attract pests and diseases. Research in the UK and India suggests that biogas systems could be build to convert the fruit wastes into methane/biogas and high quality fertilizer. These technologies are well known and successful in India, but have not been applied successfully in West Africa. This would lower production costs in the factory and make the farmers products more profitable, - convert hazardous wastes into fuel and fertilizer, - reduce deforestation caused by use of fire-wood, de-couple the fruit processing from non-sustainable butane gas dependence, - reduce health and public sanitation problems caused by the fruit wastes - reduce greenhouse gas emissions
